newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- JUNE 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- JUNE 20.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:
KATHIMERINI

--The Spraou report on measures for the economy to achieve convergence, presented to the public yesterday, has drawn fire from the business world, markets, opposition parties and from within the government itself. The report recommends a strict incomes policy for the next two years in the public and private sector and a flate-rate charge of 10 percent on company profits.

--The current account deficit widened 27.5 percent year-on-year in February to 853 million dollars versus 668 million dollars in the same month last year. The development is attributed to the increase in the trade deficit by 444.3 million dollars and to an improvement in the invisibles surplus.
--Insurance firms are looking to reduce costs due to the over-use and cost of hospital benefit cards.
--The replacement of subisidies with incentives such as susbisidised interest rates and tax breaks and a number of other changes is being considered in the development bill currently being drafted.
IMERISIA
--National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou yesterday called on bankers to reduce their lending rates and breach the gap between lending and deposit interest rates.
--Papandoniou calmed market concerns and rejected the Spraou report's proposal for a flate-rate charge on company profits, saying it was not being considered by the government.
KERDOS

--Current conditions do not lend themselves to a further fall in lending interest rates unless commercial banks reduce the difference between their lending and deposit rates, according to the central bank governor Lucas Papademos, who forecast interest rates would fall another 3.0 percent over the next two years.

--The Spraou report's proposal for a 10 percent charge on company profits is designed to give real wage increases to employees and aid in the effort to bring inflation down to 2.3 percent in 1999 and bring Greece into economic and monetary union by 2001.

--OTE, Greece's telecoms organisation, announced it had increase its profit forecast for 1997 by 21 billion drachmas, bringing the figure to a total 325 billion drachmas. The readjustment comes on the basis of first quarter returns indicating increased inflows for the state-run organisation.
--Deputy Finance Minister George Drys indicated his dissatisfaction with the performance of the country's customs services, saying they were falling short of meeting budget targets.
NAFTEMBORIKI

--Papandoniou yesterday told his crack financial crimes squad SDOE that they should chase the "big fish" evading taxes. SDOE has referred 120 businessmen and professionals to court for irregularities in its two months on the streets.
--The Federation of Greek Industries and OTE have signed a framework of principles for contracts in the telecoms sector, to esnure Greek involvement in OTE investment programmes.
EXPRESS
--A recent change in trading hours will no longer apply to tourist areas, where trading hours will be completely deregulated, according to reports.
--The development industry and national tourist organisation yesterday presented its much-discussed omnibus bill on tourism policy. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
